title: William Majcher, Retired R.C.M.P. Officer, Charged With Spying for China
description: The officer was also charged under Canada’s Security of Information Act with helping Beijing “identify and intimidate’’ an individual.

title: Russia Raises Interest Rates, Trying to Cool Wartime Economy
description: With the ruble weakening and the government spending ever more money on the war in Ukraine, Moscow took unexpectedly sharp action to curb inflation.

title: Four Charged in Gold Coin Theft From German Museum
description: The arrests came about eight months after thieves cut fiber optic cables, broke into a museum in Bavaria and stole 483 ancient gold coins, the police said.

title: Russia Ending Ukraine Grain Deal Could Upend Food Security in Africa
description: Somalia, Ethiopia and others in the Horn of Africa could be hit the hardest, a leader of an aid group said.

title: How to Fight Canada’s Wildfires in the Era of Climate Change
description: Canada’s record-breaking wildfire season shows the need to shift from suppressing fires to preventing them as fires become more difficult to combat.

title: Russia-Ukraine War: Russian Strikes and Naval Drills Unsettle Black Sea as U.N. Meets
description: The U.N. Security Council was holding an emergency meeting on the collapse of a deal that had allowed Ukraine to ship grain despite a Russian blockade. Moscow again struck granaries in the port of Odesa and the Russian Navy practiced destroying a ship in the Black Sea.

title: Amsterdam to Bar Cruise Ships From Central Terminal
description: The Dutch capital will stop cruise ships from docking in the city center as part of a campaign to curb pollution and reduce the flow of tourists.

title: Only Early Birds Will See Acropolis as Workers Strike Over Heat
description: Security guards and others say the extreme temperatures in Athens and at other historical sites are dangerous for them and for tourists. The employees are stopping work at noon at least for now.

title: 4 Takeaways From Britain’s By-Elections
description: Among the takeaways from the vote, which saw two losses for Conservatives but also one win, was that Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is down but not out.

title: Israel’s Judicial Plan Crisis Grows as Air Reservists Threaten to Stop Serving
description: In a move that experts say could significantly hurt Israel’s military readiness, pilots and other personnel issued a warning after Benjamin Netanyahu pressed ahead with a plan to limit judicial power.

title: What to Read to Understand the Unrest in France
description: Severe protests have roiled France in recent weeks, after a police officer fatally shot a French teenager of Algerian and Moroccan descent in a suburb of Paris. The demonstrations fit a longstanding pattern.

title: India Reels From Shortage of Tomatoes, a Culinary Staple
description: “We have stopped eating tomatoes in salad,” one shopper said, “and we are not making any tomato-based vegetable dishes.”

title: Russia Detains Igor Girkin, a Critic of Putin’s War Effort in Ukraine: What to Know
description: The arrest was a sign that Russia was clamping down further on dissent, even among prominent nationalists, after last month’s brief mutiny by Wagner mercenaries.

title: Why Is Switzerland — of All Places — Importing So Much Cheese?
description: The cheese-proud country has recently imported more of the stuff than it exports, a worry for farmers and traditionalists.

title: Around the Globe, Searing Heat With No Sign of Relief
description: In Asia, Europe and the United States, records are shattering, and forecasters say there’s no respite in sight.

title: Mariupol State University has graduated its newest class after fleeing its devastated home city.
Spain’s Election Puts Focus on Leading Parties’ Allies
description: Before voting Sunday, a focus on the leading parties’ allies has dominated the campaign — and obscured debate about more fundamental issues.

title: Chinguamiga Was Born in Korea, but Shines in Mexico
description: Fleeing the strictures of modern life in a hypercompetitive South Korea, a young woman found a calmer way of life in Mexico — and millions of social media followers.

title: Mariupol State University Holds Graduation at Its Campus in Exile
description: Mariupol State University, an oasis amid the war, has graduated its newest class, more than a year after fleeing its devastated home city.

title: Israel Is Divided by a Debate Over the Supreme Court’s Reach
description: The legal concept of “reasonableness,” which has allowed the Supreme Court to strike down ministerial appointments, among other things, is at the center of a domestic crisis gripping the country.

title: Grain Prices Rise After Russia Terminates Ukraine Export Deal
description: Moscow terminated a deal this week that allowing Ukraine to export its food crops, an agreement that had helped to stabilize grain prices and to ease a global food shortage.

title: C.I.A. Chief Says Wagner Mutiny Revived Questions About Putin’s Rule
description: William J. Burns gave the most detailed public account yet by a U.S. official of the damage done to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia by last month’s uprising by the mercenary group.

title: From an Ancient Soil Sample, Clues to An Ice Sheet’s Future
description: A rediscovered sample of frozen sediment, collected more than 50 years ago, highlights the vulnerability of Greenland’s ice sheet to a warming climate.

title: Why Do Australian Politicians Love Nicknames?
description: To the average voter, ScoMo might sound more comfortable than “Prime Minister Morrison.”

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Russian attacks on Ukraine’s ports.

title: Britain’s By-elections: So Far, a Win and a Defeat for the Tories
description: The governing Conservative Party lost in one electoral district but avoided defeat in Uxbridge and South Ruislip, Boris Johnson’s former seat. A third contest was still to be decided.
